intro: Bupleurum divaricatum, commonly known as the variable bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic leaves and small, blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and has a branched stem with opposite, ovate leaves. Its flowers are arranged in umbels, a common feature in the Apiaceae family, and it blooms from late spring to early summer. Bupleurum divaricatum is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to temperate climates.
